Why would anyone review a game that is over 20 years old? Well sonny, pull up a seat around my fireplace. I have something to say about your rose colored glasses of nostalgia; they don't hold up under the bright light of progress. 

Games like Monkey Island were amazing when they first came to the market. But then people learned how to make them better. By the end of the adventure game era there were games that had character stats. They had divurged so distinctly from their roots that they were dangerously close to becoming something else entirely. 

They could have very well have gone from that to point-and-click adventure RPGs, but they didn't. Partially because "THE AWARD WINNING POINT-AND-CLICK-ADVENTURE-ROLE-PLAYING-GAME" is really not that catchy, but also because it made a lot more sense just to make a genre of games that appealed to a broader audience et al, Diablo. 

CDs came out and it allowed first person point and click games like 7th Guest and Myst to survive on the growing nostalgia of older players who remembered their childhood. 

But these developers didn't realize that humor had been the major appeal of adventure games until much later (Psychonauts?), after a glut of super serious adventure games that took most of that humor out of the equation. If you're old enough, and have played adventure games, I bet there's more than a few jokes from these old games you still remember. Remember the name of the final boss in Myst? I thought not!

"Hey asshole, I thought you were going to review Monkey Island!" you squawk in your whiny, cracking prepubescent voice. 

Okay, okay... Monkey Island died long ago. It's humor only funny to folks who like archaic computer programmer humor. It's pixel-hunt-click-the-fucking-stethescope-combined-with-a-solid-gold-packet-of-gum-on-the-featherless-parakeet-logic no longer fun for anyone because they're already solved it a long time ago, or they don't have 4 hours to spend on one puzzle when there's videos of girls in bikinis french kissing cute kittens on YouTube. (I'm watching one as I write this.)

Give this game a pass. Give everything made in this nostalgic vein a pass. Yes, even the new stuff like walking dead. Give your money to developers who are working on the next big idea, not pandering to your inner 13-year-old in some desperate grab to cash in on the IP.

Or heck, give it to me. I will spend it on booze.

The special edition is as flawless as the remake fo the first game--excellent voice work, lovely art, hot-swapping between classic and special edition, and every detail clearly considered with care.

I think this game is stronger than the first in just about every way. It's longer, it's more varied, the puzles are mostly well considered  (though there are a few ridiculously nonsensical stumpers, as seems to be inevitable in this genre), and behind the excellent humorous writing is a little more meat to each character's bones.

It's a shame some of the other classics (Grim Fandango?) haven't received the same loving treatment. The quality of the remake is almost as impressive and enjoyable as the game itself. This is how you bring back a classic.

Guybrush kehrt zurück. Im zweiten Teil von Monkey Island ist Guybrush auf der Suche nachdem großen Schatz des Big Whoop. Dabei gerät er aber in ein Abenteur dessen Ausmaße er nicht abschätzen konnte. Das ist aber nicht das normale Monkey Island 2, hier handelt es sich um die Special Edition, ein Remake des Klassikers. Die Texturen und Figuren wurden komplett neu gezeichnet. Auch die Musik und Soundeffekte wurden Resampelt um Monkey Island 2 in das Jahr 2011 zu hiefen. 

Ein wirklich gelungener Remake des Klassikers, da man hier nicht nur die neue Variante des Spiels hat sondern die alte, Old School Variante durch Knopfdruck gratis dazu bekommt. Zwar leider nur in Englisch aber das lindert den Spaß an diesem Spiel in keinsterweise.

The remake keeps the feeling of the game in the updated high definition artwork, plus adds voice acting and music recorded with live instruments while keeping most of the feeling of the iMuse transitions in-tact.
